This bill continues the absolutely critical work of pushing back against President Putin‚Äôs ongoing campaign to undermine U.S. alliances, partnerships, and democratic values around the world.

Democrats were able to remove a provision that would have made it easier for defense contractors to transfer machine guns. The bill closes a loophole that that allowed Devin Kelley, convicted of domestic violence, to purchase the gun he used in a 2017 mass shooting in a TX church

Supporting service members and their families, Democrats secured the inclusion of a substantial array of provisions to promote safety and combat domestic violence and sexual harassment among military personnel.
The Defense Department is also required to report on transitional justice in Syria and to review the policy framework for military activity like the ongoing operations in Niger.

Transparency is further enhanced by requiring the President to make the total number of deployed members of the Armed Forces publicly available. It also requires the Secretary of State to report on war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide in Syria.

The bill includes major provisions on the reporting of civilian casualties in connection with U.S. military operations. The bill requires the Secretary of Defense to develop and coordinate policy for civilian casualties connected with U.S. military operations.
The bill also requires a review of whether the U.S. Armed Forces or its partners have violated laws or policies while conducting operations in Yemen.
Democrats made significant strides to advance human rights, the promotion of peace, protection of vulnerable populations abroad, and the rule of law in conflict.

As in years before, Republicans again attempted to undermine the Endangered Species Act. This year, they also tried to roll back regulations on mining nationwide, and allow for the indefinite taking of certain public lands for defense purposes.
Foremost, Democrats defeated multiple provisions that would have been extremely harmful to the environment. Environmental riders have no place in a defense bill.

Democrats fought hard and won multiple progressive outcomes in this year‚Äôs Fiscal Year 2019 National Defense Authorization Act. We do not control Congress, and we cannot get everything we want, but I am pleased that by being persistent we succeeded on many important issues.

I will continue to use my position on the Appropriations Committee to fight for the men and women stationed at YARS and ensure that the air base is properly funded. (5/5)
In 2003, I helped to setup and coordinate Operation: Save Our Airbase Reservists (SOAR) which kept YARS off the federal Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC) list. (4/5)
I have also secured $30 million for a joint project between Air Force Research Lab, America Makes, Youngstown State University, and YARS to produce 3D printed parts for the U.S. Air Force. (3/5)

Those projects include: 
- purchase of upgraded aerial spray equipment 
- design and construction of new base lodging
- King-Graves road improvements surrounding the base
- indoor firing range
- security gate upgrades

The American Humanist Association convinced the Fourth Circuit to adopt a perverse interpretation of the Establishment Clause, which in no way prohibits a war memorial on public land from featuring religious imagery.
Erected in the aftermath of World War I, the Peace Cross has stood as a testament to the courage and sacrifice of our soldiers, sailors, airmen, and marines.

The Fourth Circuit agreed, failing to recognize the history and context of the memorial and misinterpreting the Constitution. For 90 years, the families of Prince George‚Äôs County have honored America‚Äôs fallen heroes.

In the aftermath of World War I, residents in Prince George‚Äôs County erected a 40-foot Peace Cross to honor nearly 50 local men who lost their lives in the conflict. In 2014, the American Humanist Association brought a suit claiming the cross violated the Establishment Clause.
